facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 177 of 1955 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 177 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated September 28, 1953 of Nagpur High Court in First Appeal No. 115 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 28, 1953, of the former Nagpur High Court in First Appeal No. 115 of 1951,

facts.text: Nagpur High Court judgment arises out of judgment dated July 25, 1951 of Additional District Judge, Bhandara in Civil Suit No. 14-A of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and decree dated July 25, 1951, of the Court of Additional District Judge, Bhandara, in Civil Suit No. 14-A of 1957.

facts.text: Appellant is defendant Kishori Lal who claimed to be adopted son of husband of plaintiff Mst. Chaltibai.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant before us is the defendant Kishori Lal who claimed to be the adopted son, adopted by the husband of the plaintiff, Mst. Chaltibai who is the respondent in this appeal.

facts.text: Suit brought by Mst. Chaltibai, widow of Lakshminarayan, against Badrinarayan (defendant No.1) and Kishori Lal (defendant No.2) for declaration that properties in sch. B C belonged to her as heir and possession of sch. D.

anchor.surface_text: The suit out of which this appeal arises was brought by Mst. Chaltibai, the widow of Lakshminarayan, a Marwari Aggarwal of the District of Bhandara against Badrinarayan defendant No. 1 and his son Kishori Lal defendant No. 2 number appellant for a declaration that properties in sch. B C

facts.text: Badrinarayan and Lakshminarayan were two brothers; Badrinarayan elder carrying business at Raipur, Lakshminarayan younger at ancestral village Tirora.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the litigation relevant for the purpose of this judgment are these Badrinarayan and Lakshminarayan were two brothers the former who was elder was carrying on business at Raipur and the latter who was younger carried on business in the ancestral village named Tirora

facts.text: Lakshminarayan's first wife died in 1919 leaving a son and a daughter.

anchor.surface_text: Lakshminarayans first wife died in 1919 leaving a son and a daughter.

facts.text: In 1922 Lakshminarayan married respondent Mst. Chaltibai.

anchor.surface_text: In 1922 Lakshminarayan married the respondent Mst. Chaltibai.

facts.text: Lakshminarayan's son died sometime after 1922 marriage; only remaining child daughter Mst. Jamnabai married to Chotteylal.

anchor.surface_text: His son died sometime after this marriage and therefore the only remaining child of Lakshminarayan was the daughter Mst. Jamnabai who was married to one Chotteylal.

facts.text: Lakshminarayan died on January 6, 1936 of heart disease leaving estate in schs. B, C, D valued at about Rs. 30,000.

anchor.surface_text: On January 6, 1936, Lakshminarayan died of a heart disease leaving his estate which is given in schs. B, C and D and is valued at about Rs. 30,000.

facts.text: Appellant pleaded Lakshminarayan adopted Kishorilal in Jyestha (May-June) 1935, aged 13, youngest of five sons of Badrinarayan.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant pleaded that Lakshminarayan developed heart trouble in 1934. He also pleaded that because of this heart trouble Lakshminarayan became despaired of begetting a son and therefore adopted in Jaisth  May-June  1935 the appellant Kishorilal then aged 13 years who was the youngest of the five sons of his brother Badrinarayan,

facts.text: After adoption, appellant resided with Lakshminarayan, performed obsequies, placed on gaddi, turban tied, taken in lap on 13th day by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: He further pleaded that after his adoption he resided with Lakshminarayan as his adopted son and when Lakshminarayan died he performed his obsequies as such adopted son, was placed on the gaddi and the turban was tied on his head in accordance with the custom of the caste that he was on the thirteenth day  tervi  taken by the respondent Chaltibai in her lap

facts.text: Respondent continued to accept and treat appellant as adopted son up to 1946; performed his marriage in 1942.

anchor.surface_text: from Badrinarayan with the companysent and in the presence of the relations of Lakshmi- narayan on the thirteenth day of the death of Lakshminarayan that he entered into possession of the estate of the deceased Lakshminarayan and was recognised as his adopted son even by the respondent who companytinued to accept and treat him as such upto 1946 and in 1942 the respondent performed his  the appellants marriage .

facts.text: Partition in family of Badrinarayan on October 30, 1943; appellant received no share because given in adoption.

anchor.surface_text: After he attained majority he managed the estate himself and there was a partition in the family of Badrinarayan on October 30, 1943, in which the appellant, because of his having been given out in adoption in another family, received numbershare.

facts.text: Respondent denied adoption and treatment as adopted son; illiterate pardanashin woman reposed confidence in Badrinarayan who managed estate.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent in the plaint denied both the adoption and the treatment or acceptance of the appellant as an adopted son. She also stated that she was an illiterate purdanashin woman who was number companyversant with the management of business and after the death of her husband she reposed full companyfidence in Badrinarayan who assured her that he would properly look after her affairs, business and property

facts.text: Disputes led to proceedings under ss.107/145 CrPC; receiver appointed; Magistrate order dated May 19, 1947 directing civil court decision.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and his father Badrinarayan then attempted to oust her from the business and the estate of her husband which led to disputes between the parties and proceedings under ss.107 145 of the Code of Criminal Procedure were started, a receiver was appointed and the Magistrate by an order dated May 19, 1947,

facts.text: Trial court dismissed suit, held adoption proved but found against appellant on estoppel.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt dismissed the suit. It held the adoption proved but found against the appellant on the question of estoppel.

facts.text: High Court reversed trial court on factum of adoption, held no adoption; no estoppel.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on appeal reversed the finding as to the factum of adoption but upheld the finding on the question of estoppel. It was of the opinion that the respondent was number estopped on account of any misrepresentation made by her and that there was numbersuch companyduct on her part which deprived her of her right

facts.text: Supreme Court held factum of adoption not established by evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Taking all these facts into companysideration the High Court, in our opinion, has company- rectly held that the factum of adoption by Lakshminarayan has number been established.

facts.text: No estoppel applies as both parties knew true facts; no misrepresentation.

anchor.surface_text: In this case both the parties were aware of the truth of the facts and companysequently the doctrine of estoppel was inapplicable.

facts.text: School leaving certificate shows Kishorilal student at Tirora school June 22, 1936 to June 30, 1937 as son of Badrinarayan.

anchor.surface_text: The school leaving certificate shows that he was a student in the school at Tirora from June 22, 1936 to June 30, 1937, and there he was entered as the son of Badrinarayan.

facts.text: Sale deed dated January 24, 1938 by Chaltibai states adoption after death of Lakshminarayan by her.

anchor.surface_text: Therein the adoption of the appellant is stated to have taken place after the death of Lakshminarayan and was by  Chaltibai respondent under the authority of her deceased husband and with the companysent of the whole family.

facts.text: Partition of Badrinarayan family property October 30, 1943; appellant no share.

anchor.surface_text: there was a partition in the family of Badrinarayan on October 30, 1943, in which the appellant, because of his having been given out in adoption in another family, received numbershare.

facts.text: Respondent signed papers at instance of Badrinarayan without understanding.

anchor.surface_text: At his instance she  the respondent  signed certain papers without understanding them or without knowing their companytents and sometimes she even signed blank papers.

facts.text: Appellant in criminal case asserted adoption six months prior to death.

anchor.surface_text: In the criminal case the appellant, it is alleged, asserted that he had been adopted by Lakshminarain six months prior to his death, a fact which the respondent Chaltibai denied in her plaint.

issues.text: Did the deceased Lakshminarayan validly adopt the defendant No. 2 in the bright fortnight of Jyestha June , 1935 A. D.?

issues.text: Was the adoption valid according to law?

anchor.surface_text: Was the adoption valid according to law?

anchor.surface_text: The importance of accounts was emphasised by the Privy Council in Sootrugun v. Sabitra  1  in Diwakar Rao v. Chandanlal Rao  2  in Kishorilal v. Chunilal  3  in Lal Kunwar v. Charanji Lal  4  and in Padamlal v. Fakira Debya  5 . The oral evidence of witnesses deposing to the factum of adoption is both insufficient and contradictory.

precedents.cited_proposition: importance of accounts in proving adoption

anchor.surface_text: in Diwakar Rao v. Chandanlal Rao  2  in Kishorilal v. Chunilal  3  in Lal Kunwar v. Charanji Lal  4  and in Padamlal v. Fakira Debya  5 . The oral evidence of witnesses deposing to the factum of adoption is both insufficient and contradictory. Beyond their being agreed on the question of taking the appellant in adoption by Lakshminarayan the witnesses are not in accord as to the details of the adoption or as to the ceremonies or as to the usual feast following it.

precedents.cited_proposition: importance of accounts in proving adoption

anchor.surface_text: in Kishorilal v. Chunilal  3  in Lal Kunwar v. Charanji Lal  4  and in Padamlal v. Fakira Debya  5 . The oral evidence of witnesses deposing to the factum of adoption is both insufficient and contradictory. Beyond their being agreed on the question of taking the appellant in adoption by Lakshminarayan the witnesses are not in accord as to the details of the adoption or as to the ceremonies or as to the usual feast following it. The giving of presents is the only detail on which they are agreed, they all deposed that no presents were given.

anchor.surface_text: to alter his position and therefore she could not be concluded from averring a different state of things as existing at the same time. See Pickard v. Sear  1  and Square v. Square  2  . The Privy Council in Mohori Bibi v. Dhurmdas Ghogh  3   held that there can be no estoppel where the truth of the matter is known to both the parties.

See Pickard v. Sear  1  and Square v. Square  2  . The Privy Council in Mohori Bibi v. Dhurmdas Ghogh  3   held that there can be no estoppel where the truth of the matter is known to both the parties. Therefore when both the parties are equally conversant with the true facts the doctrine of estoppel is inapplicable.

The Privy Council in Mohori Bibi v. Dhurmdas Ghogh  3   held that there can be no estoppel where the truth of the matter is known to both the parties. Therefore when both the parties are equally conversant with the true facts the doctrine of estoppel is inapplicable. The documents giving rise to the plea of estoppel were four and the appellant also relied on the acts of the respondent which will be referred to later.

precedents.cited_proposition: no estoppel where truth is known to both parties

anchor.surface_text: And he cannot be allowed to set up a case different to his case in the written statement nor can he be allowed to prove his title as an adopted son on such different case. See Tayammaul v. Sashachalla Naiker  1 , Gopeelal v. Mussamat Chandraolee Buhajee  2  . The correct rule of estoppel applicable in the case of adoption is that it does not confer status.

precedents.cited_proposition: cannot set up inconsistent case; estoppel does not confer status in adoption

anchor.surface_text: See Tayammaul v. Sashachalla Naiker  1 , Gopeelal v. Mussamat Chandraolee Buhajee  2  . The correct rule of estoppel applicable in the case of adoption is that it does not confer status. It shuts out the mouth of certain persons if they try to deny the adoption, but where both parties are equally conversant with the true state of facts this doctrine has no application.

precedents.cited_proposition: cannot set up inconsistent case; estoppel does not confer status in adoption

anchor.surface_text: these two facts will not add to the efficacy of the plea of estoppel which otherwise is inapplicable Dhanraj v. Sonabai  1 . The appellant relied on Rani Dharam Kunwar v. Balwant Singh  2  which was a case where the adoptive mother, the Rani had herself in a previous proceeding pleaded that she had authority to adopt and the Privy Council were of the opinion that the question could be decided on its own facts without recourse to the doctrine of estoppel,

precedents.cited_proposition: obsequies and marriage do not support estoppel if adoption disproved

precedents.citation: Rani Dharam Kunwar v. Balwant Singh 2

anchor.surface_text: The appellant relied on Rani Dharam Kunwar v. Balwant Singh  2  which was a case where the adoptive mother, the Rani had herself in a previous proceeding pleaded that she had authority to adopt and the Privy Council were of the opinion that the question could be decided on its own facts without recourse to the doctrine of estoppel, although they did not differ from the view of the courts below as to the applicability of the doctrine of estoppel.

precedents.case_name: Rani Dharam Kunwar v Balwant Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: estoppel in adoption by authority of adoptive mother

anchor.surface_text: the admissions shifted the onus on to the respondent on the principle that what a party himself admits to be true may reasonably be presumed to be so and until the presumption was rebutted, the fact admitted must be taken to be established Chandra Kunwar v. Narpat Singh  1 . The question of onus loses its efficacy because it was never objected to in the courts below and evidence having been led by the parties, at this stage the court has to adjudicate on the material before it.

And admissions are not conclusive, and unless they constitute estoppel, the maker is at liberty to prove that they were mistaken or were untrue Trinidad Asphalt Company v. Coryat  2 . Admissions are mere pieces of evidence and if the truth of the matter is known to both parties the principle stated in Chandra Kunwars case 1 would be inapplicable.

Any admission made by a widow situated as the respondent was would necessarily carry very little weight Padamlal v. Fakira Debya  1 . Besides the four documents above mentioned the appellant Kishorilal relied on the following facts as instances of admissions and conduct of the respondent Chaltibai. The first is the performance of obsequies by the appellant and the subsequent taking of the appellant in her lap by the respondent.

precedents.cited_proposition: admissions by a widow in dependent position carry little weight

anchor.surface_text: the performance of funeral rites will not sustain an adoption unless it clearly appears that the adoption itself was performed under circumstances as would render it A.I.R. 1931 P.C. 84. 2 1865 10 M.I.A. 429. perfectly valid. But then it was submitted that the taking by the respondent of the appellant in her lap coupled with the performance of obsequies was a clear proof of her acceptance of the appellants adoption by her deceased husband.

precedents.cited_proposition: performance of funeral rites does not prove adoption unless adoption itself valid

anchor.surface_text: preponderance of evidence. If the facts are once ascertained, presumption arising from conduct cannot establish a right which the facts themselves disprove See Tayamals case  1  at p. 433. Presumptions cannot sustain an adoption even though 1 1865 10 M.I.A. 429. it might have been acquiesced in by all concerned when as in the present case, the evidence shows that the adoption did not take place.

precedents.cited_proposition: presumptions from conduct cannot establish adoption disproved by facts

It was next argued on behalf of the appellant that even though the evidence produced in support of the adoption might be unsatisfactory and number sufficient to establish the factum of adoption the respondent in this case was estopped from setting up the true facts of the case inasmuch as she represented in the former document and legal proceedings and in various other ways that the appellant was the adopted son of the deceased Lakshminarayan and thereby caused him to change his position by being transferred from the family of Badrinarayan to that of Lakshminarayan.

outcome.relief_summary: Factum of adoption not established by evidence; plea of estoppel inapplicable as both parties knew true facts; course of conduct and admissions do not prove adoption or create estoppel; High Court judgment upheld
